channel.title: www on Tushar Chandra
channel.description: Recent content in www on Tushar Chandra

item.title: What I read this week (September 20 - September 26)
item.description: This week’s reading, including “Useful things to know about engineering levels,” “Enable learning in technical writing,” and more.

item.title: [Paper] Reliance on Metrics is a Fundamental Challenge for AI
item.description: One of my more deeply held beliefs is that people rely too heavily on metrics, so when my friend Judah sent me this paper I was quick to jump on it. Rachel Thomas and David Uminsky argue that an overemphasis on metrics is a fundamental problem with AI.

item.title: [Paper] Why ask Why? Forward Causal Inference and Reverse Causal Questions
item.description: This short paper argues that reverse causal questions (“why did sales go down?") are opportunities to consider problems with existing models. The search for causal explanations, then, can help us to improve our models.

item.title: What I read this week (September 13 - September 19)
item.description: This week’s reading, including “Useful things to know about engineering levels,” “Enable learning in technical writing,” and more.

item.title: My first conference talk acceptance!
item.description: I’m excited to have had my first conference talk accepted, Learning Bayesian Statistics with Pokemon GO at PyMCon!

item.title: [Paper] Towards Fine-grained Flow Forecasting: a Graph Attention Approach for Bike Sharing Systems
item.description: In bike sharing systems, forecasting the demand for pick-ups and drop-offs at each station is essential. This paper presents a novel methodology for doing this, which uses graph neural networks and a spatiotemporal design for station-by-station flow forecasting.

item.title: [Paper] Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts
item.description: What kinds of challenges arise when communicating election forecasts, as FiveThirtyEight, The Economist, and a host of others are attempting to do? How do you best discuss your predictions and uncertainty? What responsibilities do forecasters have? Andrew Gelman, Jessica Hullman, and Christopher Wlezien discuss.

item.title: My review of Indistractable
item.description: I review Nir Eyal’s Indistractable, a quick read that took me less than a week. I found valuable advice for improving my concentration and attention, and I’m excited to apply some of these ideas to my life.

item.title: #republic: closing thoughts
item.description: My final thoughts on Cass Sunstein’s #republic. I talk about what it means to reimagine today’s republic, and how Sunstein’s book encourages us to rethink the relationship between technology and democracy.

item.title: Early thoughts from Indistractable
item.description: My next book is Indistractable by Nir Eyal. The book’s tagline is “how to control your attention and choose your life,” which is compelling! My early thoughts are mixed between grateful and skeptical.

item.title: [Paper] A Framework for Understanding Unintended Consequences of Machine Learning
item.description: What does it really mean for a machine learning system to be “biased”? Lots of different things, potentially, to the point where the term being so overloaded has started causing confusion. This paper presents six different categories of bias in machine learning.

item.title: On speech
item.description: Towards the end of #republic, we study speech and its regulation by government. What are reasonable limits that a government might pose on speech? How might these change in the digital era?

item.title: Consumers and citzens
item.description: One of the recurring themes in Sunstein’s book is on the conflict between consumer sovereignty and political sovereignty. The roles of citizen and consumer are different, and we each play both. This post explores this idea a little bit.

item.title: Shared experiences and information
item.description: How is the internet changing shared experiences? What happens when people are walled off from each other more than they were before? This post explores how the internet is contributing to fewer shared experiences, and how this can occasionally be in conflict with democratic ideals.

item.title: #republic: early thoughts
item.description: What does democracy look like in the age of social media? How do we reimagine public spaces for the digital era? What kinds of groups should the internet promote? These are questions posed by Cass Sunstein’s book #republic.

item.title: What I read this week (August 30 - September 5)
item.description: This week’s reading includes articles on imposter syndrome, career lessons, and writing more.

item.title: [Paper] WES: Agent-based User Interaction Simulation on Real Infrastructure
item.description: In this paper, Facebook simulates itself. Through legions of bots trained through reinforcement learning, but running on the real Facebook platform, Facebook details how it created a web-enabled simulation system of its own platform.

item.title: What I read this week (August 23 - 29)
item.description: My last week of vacation. I’ve been reading Cass Sunstein’s #republic and the usual stuff from newsletters and Twitter.

item.title: [Paper] Equality of Opportunity in Supervised Learning
item.description: Measuring the (un)fairness of a predictive model is challenging work. This NeurIPS paper motivates and defines two concepts for this, “equalized odds” and “equal opportunity.” It then develops a a post-training framework to induce these new notions of fairness onto a trained model.

item.title: What I read this week (August 16 - 22)
item.description: I did a lot of reading this week—articles shared on Twitter, from newsletters, or passed along by friends. Topics include AI bias, data science careers, technical debt and testing data science systems, and more.
